field_edited_text.value:
Summary





MARYLAND’S waterways have developed into a traffic problem since
the advent of the automobile as a major means of transportation. The first
major step in solving this problem was taken by the State Roads Commis-
sion in the development of Maryland’s Primary Bridge Program. This
program includes two projects, the first a north-south highway and the
second a crossing of the Chesapeake Bay. The north-south highway crosses
three of the principal tributaries of the Chesapeake Bay—Susquehanna
River, Patapsco River and Potomac River. This engineering report covers
bridge structures to carry the north-south highway across these water-
ways and in addition it covers a tunnel as a possible alternate method for
crossing the Patapsco River. This report covers also a bridge structure to
carry a highway across the Chesapeake Bay to connect the Eastern and
Western Shores of the State, such bridge to be located either at the Millers
Island—Tolchester site or at the Sandy Point—Kent Island site.

All crossings are over navigable waters under the jurisdiction of the United
States War Department, and engineers for this department have signified
their approval of four of the plans presented in this report. One bridge,
that across the Susquehanna River, has been formally approved by the
War Department. The War Department Engineers have deferred action on
the Chesapeake Bay Bridge from Millers Island to Tolchester.

Traffic conditions and estimates indicate a necessity for four traffic lanes
at the Susquehanna and Patapsco River crossings, whereas two traffic lanes
will suffice for all other crossings.

The long span and high clearance requirements for navigation, as well
as engineering economics, make necessary the use of steel spans for all the
bridges. »

Each of the crossings includes approach roadways and new highway ap-
proaches beyond the limits of the immediate approach roadways are con-
templated under separate programs.

The Susquehanna River Bridge will be a part of the Governor Harry W.

167
